body:
$SPY "Diamond hands" is an interesting term. 
It's thought to be for a long term investor but if you read about it, it says "to ignore dips and volatility and hold your position." 

Now to me a long term investor is already doing this,  but a DAY TRADER , or, yeah, swing too, of course, maybe, more so, is not just holding a stock for YEARS.
For DTs and STs, it's seconds, minutes, day, or, days, or, week, or, two, maybe, up to 3, on a swing, but that's cut-off, IMO, let's debate theclatter later please $QQQ $SOXX $AAPL

$BTC.X People have a lot to say about crypto but one things for sure it’s not the stock market, these corrections/crashes are normal in my opinion because cryptocurrency will always be more volatile than the stock market. $AAPL MC almost $3T the entire MC of cryptocurrency is less than $3T…BTC still outpacing the S&P since inception…..

links.title: Apple Has a $6 Billion Supply Chain Problem (That May Get Worse)
links.description: Success creates problems. And, not having enough iPhones, Macs, and iPads to sell because you have sold so many counts as a good problem, but it's a problem nonetheless. Apple had a pretty amazing past year which was driven not just by its products, but also its services.

Apple is a $3 Trillion Stock – Week in Review
January 9, 2022. 

Apple (AAPL) was briefly a $3 trillion stock on January 4th, the first day the stock market opened in 2022. The stock price climbed over $182.86 per share on optimism about an electric vehicle, augmented-reality glasses, and other products. Alas, Apple’s stock price dropped the remainder of the week as a negative sentiment about rising interest rates impacted tech stocks and the NASDAQ. Apple’s market capitalization finished the week at $2.824 trillion.

https://www.dividendpower.org/2022/01/09/apple-is-a-3-trillion-stock-week-in-review/

message.body: @UntamedBull @MrChipe Apple borrowed 14 billion last year in Jan 2021. Thry borrowed to fund their stock buy backs. They borrowed instead of tapping into their cash reserves because the interest rates are low. If the interest rates are higher, they might not borrow and have to tap into their own cash. Worse yet, they could stop the buy back. Or they might stop increasing their dividends. They might stop venturing into building a fancy new toy on the side which they initially planned but won't because they now have an additional burden of a 140 million dollars a year. People might stop buying apple stock as they did earlier because they don't want to use their margins and pay higher rates. Remember that 1 percent increase at the fed translates into higher interest rates down the stream. It's a chain reaction. If this is the condition of the richest company in the world, imagine the plight of the rest.
